questions.question: They went out despite of the rain.
questions.description: ‘Of’ should be removed from the sentence. The correct preposition is despite.

questions.question: Merlin, who is my youngest sister, she lives in Qatar.
questions.description: ‘She’ should be removed from the sentence. A clause cannot have more than one subject.

questions.question: No matter what that I do, nothing seems to work.
questions.description: ‘That’ should be removed from the sentence.

questions.question: He is at the work and won’t be home before evening.
questions.description: ‘The’ should be removed from the sentence. There is no article in the expression ‘at work’.

questions.question: It is getting dark. Let us go to home.
questions.description: Home is used without to as an adverb referring to direction.

questions.question: I have received the parcel last week.
questions.description: We cannot use the present perfect tense with past time expressions.

questions.question: You had better to put the meat in the oven.
questions.description: After had better we use the infinitive without to.

questions.question: You have to tell to me exactly how it happened.
questions.description: We do not use a preposition between tell and its object. The sentence should read: You have to tell me exactly how it happened.

questions.question: If something does not work, I usually give to it a kick.
questions.description: There is no preposition between give and an indirect object.

questions.question: I don’t know that how we are going to get over the river.
questions.description: ‘That’ should be removed from the sentence. The sentence should read: I don’t know how we are going to get over the river.

questions.question: Have you ever tried to get a toothpaste back into the tube?
questions.description: The article ‘a’ should be removed.

questions.question: We have got our roof blown off in the storm last week.
questions.description: We cannot use the present perfect tense with past time expressions.

questions.question: I might can be able to help.
questions.description: Can should be removed. The sentence should read: I might be able to help.

questions.question: I came as much quickly as I could.
questions.description: Before adjectives and adverbs, as is used without much.

questions.question: I don’t care how much expensive that laptop is. I am going to buy it.
questions.description: Before adjectives and adverbs how is used without much.

questions.question: You are quite rather a nuisance.
questions.description: Quite and rather have very similar meanings. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: Do not talk such a nonsense!
questions.description: Such is used without a before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I have been to quite too many countries recently.
questions.description: Quite should be removed. Quite cannot modify too many or too much.

questions.question: Most of people do not understand philosophy.
questions.description: We use most without of before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: I have read all six of novels by Jane Austen.
questions.description: Of is omitted before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: Although I was not interested in the lecture, but I sat through it.
questions.description: Although and but have very similar meanings. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: Though he started early but he arrived last.
questions.description: Though and but have very similar meanings. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: It is a small house. Besides, it also needs a lot of repairs.
questions.description: Besides and also mean the same. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: I will never forget meeting you on that afternoon.
questions.description: Prepositions are not normally used before expressions beginning with next or last.
